title: Prolapsed Umbilical Cord - Positioning
pcr_text: 28-year-old pregnant woman, 38 weeks, membranes ruptured, umbilical cord visible at vaginal opening. How should you position her?
correct_error: Prolapsed cord: position mother in Trendelenburg or knee-chest position to relieve pressure on cord per OB protocols.

options.text: Position in Trendelenburg (head down) or knee-chest to relieve cord compression
Keep her supine to maintain blood flow
options.feedback: CRITICAL ERROR! Supine position increases cord compression. Use Trendelenburg.

options.text: Elevate her legs to improve circulation

title: Pediatric Respiratory Distress - Appearance
pcr_text: 2-year-old with wheezing, retractions, nasal flaring. Using the Appearance/Work of Breathing/Circulation triangle, what does the child's appearance indicate?
correct_error: Pediatric assessment triangle: appearance (mental status), work of breathing, circulation per pediatric protocols.

options.text: Work of breathing: retractions and nasal flaring
options.feedback: PARTIAL! This describes work of breathing, but appearance shows mental status changes.

title: Breech Birth Management
pcr_text: 32-year-old in active labor, fetal buttocks presenting first. Should you attempt delivery or transport immediately?
correct_error: Breech presentation: transport to hospital - vaginal delivery contraindicated per OB protocols.

options.text: Transport immediately - breech delivery requires C-section
Attempt vaginal delivery with mother pushing
options.feedback: CRITICAL ERROR! Breech vaginal delivery can cause fetal injury. Transport immediately.

options.text: Wait for head to turn to vertex

title: TEI Hotspot: Infant Pulse Assessment
pcr_text: 6-month-old infant unresponsive. Where do you assess the pulse on an infant?
correct_error: Infant pulse assessment: brachial artery (anteromedial aspect of arm) per pediatric protocols.

options.text: Brachial artery - anteromedial aspect of upper arm

options.feedback: INCORRECT! Carotid pulse difficult in infants. Use brachial artery.

title: Preeclampsia Recognition
pcr_text: 30-year-old pregnant, 32 weeks, severe headache, blurred vision, BP 170/110, 2+ protein in urine. What condition is this?
correct_error: Preeclampsia: hypertension, proteinuria, headache/visual changes in pregnancy per OB protocols.

options.text: Preeclampsia - transport immediately for magnesium sulfate

options.feedback: CRITICAL ERROR! Severe hypertension with proteinuria = preeclampsia requiring immediate transport.

title: Pediatric Respiratory Failure - Work of Breathing
pcr_text: 4-month-old with RSV, head bobbing, seesaw breathing, cyanotic. What does the work of breathing indicate?
correct_error: Work of breathing assessment: head bobbing and seesaw breathing indicate severe respiratory failure per pediatric triangle.

options.text: Work of breathing: severe - head bobbing, seesaw respirations indicate failure

options.feedback: PARTIAL! Lethargy is appearance, but work of breathing shows severe compromise.

title: Autism Spectrum Disorder - Patient Assessment
pcr_text: 8-year-old with autism, nonverbal, self-injurious behavior, mother states 'this is normal for him'. Should you treat as behavioral or assess for injury?
correct_error: Autism: assess for injury despite baseline behaviors - don't assume self-injury is normal per special populations protocols.

options.text: Assess for injury - autism doesn't preclude trauma
Accept mother's explanation - no assessment needed
options.feedback: CRITICAL ERROR! Always assess for injury regardless of developmental disability.

title: Postpartum Hemorrhage
pcr_text: 25-year-old post-delivery, soaking through pads rapidly, BP 90/60, HR 120. What is the immediate treatment?
correct_error: Postpartum hemorrhage: fundal massage, transport immediately per OB protocols.

options.feedback: INCORRECT! Fundal massage is primary treatment for uterine atony.

title: TEI Hotspot: Pediatric IV Site
pcr_text: 3-year-old needing IV access. Where is the preferred site for pediatric IV insertion?
correct_error: Pediatric IV sites: scalp veins preferred for infants, hands/forearms for children per pediatric protocols.

options.text: Scalp veins (infants) or dorsum of hand/forearm (toddlers)

options.feedback: DANGEROUS! Central lines require advanced training. Use peripheral sites.

title: Dementia - Wandering Patient
pcr_text: 75-year-old with dementia found wandering streets, confused, hypothermic. Should you transport or return to facility?
correct_error: Dementia patient with medical emergency: treat condition first, then address disposition per special populations protocols.

options.text: Treat hypothermia and transport to ED for evaluation

options.feedback: INCORRECT! Medical emergencies take precedence over returning to facility.

options.text: Wait for family to pick up

title: Placental Abruption
pcr_text: 35-year-old pregnant, severe abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, rigid abdomen, fetal bradycardia. What is this?
correct_error: Placental abruption: painful vaginal bleeding, rigid abdomen, fetal distress per OB protocols.

options.text: Placental abruption - transport immediately in left lateral position

options.feedback: CRITICAL ERROR! Painful bleeding with rigid abdomen = abruption requiring immediate transport.

title: Pediatric Circulation Assessment
pcr_text: 18-month-old febrile, mottled skin, delayed capillary refill, weak pulses. What does circulation assessment show?
correct_error: Circulation assessment: capillary refill, pulses, skin color indicate perfusion status per pediatric triangle.

options.text: Circulation: poor perfusion - delayed cap refill, mottled skin

options.feedback: PARTIAL! Irritability is appearance, but circulation shows perfusion problems.

title: LVAD Patient - Device Malfunction
pcr_text: 55-year-old with LVAD (HeartMate), presents with device alarm sounding, patient hypotensive. What should you do?
correct_error: LVAD malfunction: do not disconnect device, transport immediately per special populations protocols.

options.text: Transport immediately - do not disconnect LVAD

options.feedback: CRITICAL ERROR! Never disconnect LVAD. Device maintains circulation.

title: TEI Hotspot: Newborn Pulse Assessment
pcr_text: Newborn just delivered, not breathing well. Where do you assess pulse on a newborn?
correct_error: Newborn pulse: umbilical cord initially, then brachial artery per neonatal protocols.

options.text: Umbilical cord initially, then brachial artery

options.feedback: DIFFICULT! Umbilical cord provides easiest access for newborns.

title: Shoulder Dystocia
pcr_text: 29-year-old in labor, head delivered but shoulders stuck, mother cannot push further. What is this complication?
correct_error: Shoulder dystocia: shoulders stuck after head delivery, requires specific maneuvers per OB protocols.

options.text: Shoulder dystocia - call for OB assistance immediately
Apply suprapubic pressure to release shoulders
options.feedback: OUT OF SCOPE! Shoulder dystocia requires specialized OB maneuvers.

options.text: Wait for shoulders to deliver spontaneously

title: Pediatric Asthma - Respiratory Distress
pcr_text: 5-year-old with asthma, tripod position, using accessory muscles, speaking in 2-word sentences. Respiratory status?
correct_error: Pediatric asthma: tripod position and accessory muscle use indicate severe respiratory distress per triangle assessment.

options.text: Severe respiratory distress - tripod position, accessory muscles
Mild respiratory distress - still speaking in sentences
options.feedback: INCORRECT! Tripod position and 2-word sentences indicate severe distress.

title: Autism - Sensory Overload
pcr_text: 12-year-old autistic child having meltdown at scene, covering ears, rocking. Should you restrain or de-escalate?
correct_error: Autism sensory overload: reduce stimuli, allow coping mechanisms per special populations protocols.

options.text: Reduce sensory input and allow coping behaviors

options.feedback: INCORRECT! Restraint can increase agitation. Use de-escalation techniques.

title: Preterm Labor
pcr_text: 26-year-old pregnant at 32 weeks, regular contractions every 5 minutes, cervical dilation. Should you transport or attempt to stop labor?
correct_error: Preterm labor: transport immediately - tocolytics require hospital administration per OB protocols.

options.text: Transport immediately - preterm delivery requires NICU
Attempt to stop labor with medications
options.feedback: OUT OF SCOPE! Tocolytics require hospital administration.

options.text: Wait for contractions to space out

title: TEI Hotspot: Pediatric Blood Pressure
pcr_text: 7-year-old in shock. Where do you place the blood pressure cuff on a child?
correct_error: Pediatric BP: use appropriate cuff size on upper arm per pediatric protocols.

options.text: Upper arm with cuff width 2/3 of upper arm length

options.feedback: INCORRECT! Upper arm is standard location for accurate readings.

title: Dementia - Sundowning Syndrome
pcr_text: 80-year-old with dementia, agitated and confused at dusk, trying to leave facility. Should you restrain or redirect?
correct_error: Sundowning: redirect and reorient gently per dementia protocols.

options.text: Redirect and reorient using calm approach

options.feedback: INCORRECT! Restraint increases confusion. Use redirection techniques.

options.text: Allow patient to leave if they want

title: Cord Around Neck
pcr_text: 31-year-old delivering, umbilical cord wrapped around baby's neck. Should you cut the cord or wait for OB?
correct_error: Nuchal cord: do not cut cord - attempt to slip over head or wait for OB per delivery protocols.

options.text: Attempt to slip cord over head or wait for OB assistance
Cut cord immediately to deliver baby
options.feedback: DANGEROUS! Cutting cord can cause fetal hemorrhage. Slip over head instead.

title: Pediatric Febrile Seizure
pcr_text: 2-year-old post-seizure, temp 104Â°F, now alert but lethargic. What is the most likely cause?
correct_error: Febrile seizure: common in children 6 months-5 years with rapid temperature increase per pediatric protocols.

options.text: Febrile seizure - most common cause of seizures in this age

options.feedback: POSSIBLE but febrile seizure more likely. Assess for meningeal signs.

title: LVAD Patient - Normal Operation
pcr_text: 60-year-old with LVAD presenting with chest pain. Device humming normally. Should you perform CPR if patient arrests?
correct_error: LVAD patient: device maintains circulation, CPR may be ineffective per special populations protocols.

options.text: CPR may be ineffective - LVAD maintains circulation

options.feedback: INEFFECTIVE! LVAD provides circulation. Focus on reversible causes.

options.text: Disconnect LVAD to allow manual compressions

title: TEI Hotspot: Pediatric Stethoscope Placement
pcr_text: 4-month-old with respiratory distress. Where do you place the stethoscope for lung assessment?
correct_error: Pediatric lung assessment: anterior chest preferred due to thin chest wall per pediatric protocols.

options.text: Anterior chest - thin chest wall allows better auscultation

options.feedback: DIFFICULT! Anterior approach preferred for infants and small children.

title: Eclampsia
pcr_text: 28-year-old pregnant with preeclampsia now seizing. What medication should be administered?
correct_error: Eclampsia: magnesium sulfate for seizure control per OB protocols.

options.feedback: INCORRECT! Magnesium is first-line for eclampsia, diazepam second-line.

title: Pediatric Anaphylaxis
pcr_text: 3-year-old with bee sting, facial swelling, stridor, hypotension. What is the immediate treatment?
correct_error: Pediatric anaphylaxis: epinephrine IM, airway management per pediatric protocols.

options.feedback: INSUFFICIENT! Epinephrine is first-line for anaphylaxis with airway involvement.

title: Autism - Communication Challenges
pcr_text: 15-year-old autistic patient, nonverbal, in pain but unable to communicate. How do you assess pain level?
correct_error: Autism pain assessment: observe behaviors, use pain scales adapted for nonverbal patients per special populations protocols.

options.text: Observe behavioral indicators and use nonverbal pain scales
Assume no pain since patient can't communicate
options.feedback: CRITICAL ERROR! Autistic patients feel pain but may not express it typically.

title: Meconium Staining
pcr_text: Newborn delivered with meconium-stained fluid, baby vigorous. Should you suction the airway?
correct_error: Meconium: suction only if baby depressed, not if vigorous per neonatal protocols.

options.text: No suction needed - baby is vigorous
Deep suction of mouth and nose
options.feedback: INCORRECT! Vigorous babies do not need suctioning, may cause bradycardia.

title: TEI Hotspot: Pediatric CPR Ratio
pcr_text: Child in cardiac arrest. What is the compression to ventilation ratio for pediatric CPR?
correct_error: Pediatric CPR: 15:2 compression to ventilation ratio for single rescuer per pediatric protocols.

options.feedback: INCORRECT! Adult ratio is 30:2, pediatric is 15:2.

title: LVAD Patient - Power Failure
pcr_text: 50-year-old LVAD patient, device battery dying, patient asymptomatic. What should you do?
correct_error: LVAD battery failure: connect to external power immediately per special populations protocols.

options.text: Connect to external power source or backup battery

options.feedback: INCORRECT! Connect power first, then transport if needed.

options.text: Disconnect LVAD to use manual CPR
